# Reserve Management

The investment environment in 2022 was exceptionally volatile, with prices across multiple asset classes declining simultaneously. This not only undermined the traditional investment wisdom that holding stocks and bonds together could mitigate risk but also became the first year in nearly half a century where stocks, bonds, and major non-US currency exchanges all recorded negative returns. Under such adverse investment conditions, the Exchange Fund achieved an investment return rate of -4.5% in 2022. Compared to the significant losses suffered by most multi-asset funds during the year, the performance of the Exchange Fund reflected the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's (HKMA) diversified long-term asset allocation, as well as defensive deployments and strategic adjustments made in response to the latest external developments, effectively mitigating the impact of market turbulence.

# Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, and it may also be used to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's monetary and financial system, thereby preserving Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. The HKMA is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the utilization and investment management of the Exchange Fund, based on powers and delegated authority granted by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has set the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:
(i) Protecting capital;
(ii) Ensuring that the overall monetary base is fully supported by highly liquid US dollar assets at all times;
(iii) Ensuring sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(iv) Seeking investment returns as much as possible under the premise of meeting the above (i) to (iii) items, to safeguard the long-term purchasing power of the Exchange Fund.

These objectives comprehensively reflect the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and have been reflected in the portfolio structure and target asset allocation of the Exchange Fund (Figure 1).

Figure 1 Exchange Fund Investment Portfolio Categories

The Exchange Fund is generally divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets, which provide full support for the monetary base according to the Currency Board system. The Investment Portfolio mainly invests in bond and equity markets of economies belonging to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to preserve the value and long-term purchasing power of assets.

To better manage risks and enhance medium-to-long-term returns, the HKMA has gradually and prudently allocated part of the Exchange Fund's assets to more diversified asset categories, including emerging market and Mainland China bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure) and real estate. Emerging market and Mainland China bonds and equities are held by the Investment Portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the Long-Term Growth Portfolio. The target asset allocation of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio and other asset categories are formulated in accordance with prudent risk management principles and portfolio diversification strategies.

The Strategic Assets Portfolio was established in 2007 and has continuously held shares of The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Government for strategic purposes. Due to its unique nature, the performance of the Exchange Fund does not include this portfolio in its assessment.

# Deposits in the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations. The interest rate is generally linked to the performance of the Investment Portfolio, although future funds are primarily individual cases. The interest rate for future funds is linked to the returns of both the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio, with the actual interest rate depending on the proportion of the portfolio. In 2022, the proportion of Future Funds between the Investment Portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio was approximately 35:65.

# Investment Procedures

The investment procedures of the Exchange Fund are based on strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation is reflected in the form of investment benchmarks, i.e., the long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make to achieve its investment objectives. With strategic allocation as a guide, the Exchange Fund seeks to exceed benchmark returns through tactical asset allocation. Therefore, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocations is called "tactical deviation." After consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, the Financial Secretary sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits, and the HKMA is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and specify the allowable range of tactical deviations. Portfolio managers can manage their holdings within the allowable range of tactical deviations to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investments

The Exchange Fund Investment Office of the HKMA is responsible for the investment and related risk management functions of the Exchange Fund. The office's staff directly manages approximately 70% of the Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire Support Portfolio and parts of the Investment Portfolio. This internally managed portion of the portfolio includes various global fixed-income market investments and executes the Exchange Fund's macro risk management strategy through derivative instruments.

# External Investment Managers

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the HKMA also employs external investment managers to manage approximately 30% of the Exchange Fund's assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special asset categories. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to utilize the best professional investment talents in the market to invest in the Exchange Fund, obtain sustainable returns, and allow the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as gain insights and specialized investment knowledge from the market.

The relevant expenses for employing external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses vary annually due to market factors.

# Risk Management and Oversight

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, the importance of risk management cannot be overstated. The HKMA has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and external investment managers, and has implemented rigorous risk monitoring and compliance systems. The HKMA has established three lines of defense for investment-related activities to implement effective risk management and governance. The HKMA regularly monitors key investment risk categories (including credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks), and the establishment of risk management procedures provides a solid framework for the Exchange Fund's strategic planning and diversified investments.

# Responsible Investment

The HKMA believes that emphasizing responsible investment and considering the sustainable long-term performance of investments can more effectively achieve the investment objectives of the Exchange Fund and reduce environmental, social, and governance (ESG) related risks involved in investment activities. When ESG investments are comparable in risk-adjusted long-term returns to other investment projects, the HKMA generally prioritizes ESG investments according to established guiding principles and has integrated ESG factors into the investment management processes of both public and private markets of the Exchange Fund. For details on the HKMA's responsible investment framework and implementation, please refer to the "Responsible Investment" chapter in the "Sustainability Report 2022."

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2022

Global financial markets experienced abnormal volatility in 2022, with the bond market and stock market recording cumulative declines of 16.2% and 19.8%, respectively, with significant drops.

Due to surging global inflation, tight monetary policies, and slowing economic growth, major stock indices declined significantly throughout the year. Although global stock markets rebounded slightly at the end of the year amid expectations of inflation and interest rate peaks, the US Standard & Poor's 500 Index still fell 19.4% for the year, while the Hang Seng Index fell 15.5%.

With aggressive interest rate hikes by central banks to combat inflation, leading to sustained increases in government bond yields in major markets. The U.S. 10-year Treasury yield rose from 1.63% at the beginning of 2022 to over 4% in the fourth quarter, reaching the highest level since 2008. The U.S. Treasury yield curve began to invert from mid-year, with the inversion widening further, deepening market concerns about economic recession.

In the money market, driven by consecutive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, the U.S. dollar strengthened significantly in 2022. Other major currencies, including the euro, pound sterling, Japanese yen, and yuan, depreciated against the U.S. dollar, with the pound sterling and Japanese yen falling 10.7% and 12.2% against the U.S. dollar, respectively.

Table 1 shows the performance of major currencies, bond markets, and stock markets in 2022.

Table 1 2022 Market Returns

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund recorded an investment loss of HK$205.4 billion in 2022, including a loss of HK$53.2 billion from bond investments, a loss of HK$80.5 billion from equity investments (which includes a loss of HK$61.0 billion from overseas equity investments and a loss of HK$19.5 billion from Hong Kong equity investments), a reduction of HK$40.0 billion in foreign exchange valuations of non-Hong Kong dollar assets, and a loss of HK$31.7 billion from other investments held by subsidiaries of the Exchange Fund's investment holding companies. On the other hand, the Strategic Assets Portfolio recorded a valuation loss of HK$8.7 billion.

By the end of 2022, the total assets of the Exchange Fund reached HK$4,008 billion. The total market value of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio's investments was HK$484.7 billion, with private equity amounting to HK$370 billion and real estate amounting to HK$114.7 billion. The total amount of commitments made but not yet drawn down for investment in the Long-Term Growth Portfolio was HK$270.8 billion.

The investment return rate of the Exchange Fund (excluding the Strategic Assets Portfolio) in 2022 was -4.5%, with the Investment Portfolio achieving a return rate of -8.6% and the Support Portfolio achieving a return rate of -0.4%. The long-term growth portfolio has achieved an annualized internal return rate of 12.6% since its investment started in 2009.

Figure 1 shows the annual return rates of the Exchange Fund from 1994 to 2022. Table 2 shows the investment return rate of the Exchange Fund in 2022 and the average investment return rates for different periods. The average return rate of the Exchange Fund from 2020 to 2022 was 1.5%, from 2018 to 2022 was 2.3%, from 2013 to 2022 was 2.4%, and since 1994 was 4.5%. Table 3 lists the currency composition of the Exchange Fund's assets as of December 31, 2022.

For the audited 2022 annual financial statements of the Exchange Fund, see pages 173 to 281.

# 機構職能

機構職能部門支持金管局的運作，保持高透明度與問責性，並發揮卓越的效率及專業水準。為促進公眾對金管局的政策及工作的了解，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體、網站、資訊中心及其他渠道與整體社會及市場保持有效聯繫。

對內，金管局悉心建立一支強調靈活應變及可持續發展的工作團隊，同時遵守嚴格的財政紀律及提升資訊科技能力，應對變化及確保有效執行各項政策及措施。

# 保持透明度

# 傳媒關係與社交媒體

金管局與傳媒緊密聯繫，以提高透明度及增進公眾對金管局政策及運作的了解。金管局在2022年共舉辦或參與112次實體及線上活動，包括8次新聞發布會、11次即場訪問及93次其他公開活動。金管局另又安排46次媒體訪談。年內共發布492份雙語新聞稿，每日亦處理大量傳媒查詢。

為增進社會對金管局主要職能的認識，金管局為本地、內地及海外媒體舉辦新聞發布會及傳媒簡報會，涵蓋貨幣發行局運作、綠色與可持續金融，以及央行數碼貨幣等主題。

不同媒體積極參與金管局在2022年舉辦的活動，包括「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期3日，深受媒體關注，共有來自87個媒體200多位記者出席採訪，並在本地、區內及國際媒體發布約1,000篇新聞報導。除此之外，該活動共為30個媒體安排串流直播。

為有效聯繫公眾，金管局共營運6個社交媒體專頁（包括 Facebook、Instagram、LinkedIn、Twitter、WeChat及YouTube），獲超過100,000名用戶關注。金管局在2022年增設WeChat專頁，接觸更闊層面的受眾。金管局利用社交媒體宣傳大型盛事及項目，包括「國際金融領袖投資峰會」及政府綠色債券計劃，並提高公眾對聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）、金融科技及防騙等多個範疇的認知。

金管局總裁余偉文先生於「國際金融領袖投資峰會」接受媒體即場訪問

金管局總裁余偉文先生於「香港金融科技周2022」發表開幕主題演講

金管局副總裁阮國恒先生於數碼港與埃森哲合辦的「金融科技精英論壇2022」上發言

金管局副總裁李達志先生主持新聞發布會闡述金管局對於「數碼港元」的政策立場

金管局副總裁陳維民先生於2022金融街論壇年會作視像致辭

# 公眾查詢

公眾查詢服務是增進市民對金管局主要職能及運作認識的有效渠道，在2022年共處理9,952宗查詢。其中約有一半涉及銀行消費者事宜、銀行業政策及規例、紙幣與硬幣、金融基建及債券市場發展。當中較多查詢是關於硬幣收集計劃、銀行產品及服務、銀行業相關指引與通告，以及零售債券發行計劃。

圖1顯示自2019年以來每年接獲的公眾查詢總數，圖2列出2022年各類查詢所佔比例。

圖2 按性質列出2022年接獲的查詢

# 刊物

除金管局《年報》外，金管局出版2期《貨幣與金融穩定情況半年度報告》及4期《季報》，並定期更新《金融數據月報》資料，提供有關香港貨幣、銀行業及經濟事務的最新及專題資料與分析。此外，金管局發表17篇《匯思》文章，介紹金管局的重要措施及政策，並討論公眾關注的事項。

金管局《二零二一年年報》在香港管理專業協會2022年度最佳年報評選中獲得「非牟利及慈善機構」類銀獎，以及「環境、社會及管治匯報」優異獎。

# 機構網站

機構網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)提供46,000多頁英文及繁簡字體中文版資料，方便公眾查閱金管局的最新資訊。網站亦載有根據《銀行業條例》第20條備存的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，以及根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》備存的「儲值支付工具持牌人紀錄冊」。

金管局自2018年起透過開放應用程式介面（開放API），分階段發放在其網站所載的金融數據及重要資訊。截至2022年底，金管局依照原定計劃在網站推出合共148組開放API。

# 資訊中心

金管局資訊中心設於國際金融中心2期55樓，是向公眾介紹金管局工作及提高公眾對貨幣與銀行業事宜的了解的重要設施。資訊中心分為展覽館及圖書館兩部分。展覽館以互動方式介紹金管局的工作，以及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展；另備資料與展品，供研究香港貨幣、銀行業與金融事務。毗鄰展覽館的圖書館收藏超過26,000冊書籍、期刊及其他刊物，涵蓋香港貨幣、銀行業、金融和中央銀行事務等課題。圖書館亦按照《銀行業條例》第20條規定備存「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，供公眾查閱。

隨着疫情漸趨穩定，資訊中心於2022年下半年逐步恢復公眾導賞服務

經裝修後，全新的圖書館於2023年3月向公眾重開

# 社區聯繫及公眾教育

為與社區保持聯繫及增進市民對金管局工作的認識，金管局自1998年起推出公眾教育講座。於2022年，金管局舉行網上講座，吸引2,200多名來自82間中學的師生參加。講座內容涵蓋金管局工作簡介、聯匯制度、香港鈔票、保障個人數碼鎖匙、存款保障計劃及銀行業發展機遇。公眾教育講座至今錄得參加者人數超過 65,000 名。

金管局教育及聯繫公眾，提醒他們如何做個精明及負責任的金融服務消費者。鑑於「網絡釣魚」騙案增加，金管局推出跨媒體宣傳活動，進一步提醒市民防範聲稱來自銀行的手機短訊和電郵所載的偽冒超連結，並慎防涉及存款與信用卡等其他類型的行騙手法。金管局亦舉辦電台及社交媒體宣傳活動，發放信用卡、個人貸款、網上購物及其他支付方式（包括「先買後付」產品）的精明使用貼士。

以「數碼KEY睇緊啲，撳LINK前要三思！」為題的全新短片

為協助市民與時並進，緊貼金融科技服務的發展，金管局透過社交媒體及電台宣傳鼓勵公眾於農曆新年期間派發電子利是。金管局製作動畫短片，講解開放API，並介紹利用第三方服務供應商（例如網上購物平台及按揭服務公司）的手機應用程式使用銀行服務需注意的事項。動畫短片亦介紹「轉數快」的App-to-App及Web-to-App支付功能及優點。

動畫短片有助增進公眾的數碼金融知識

金管局亦致力加深公眾對金融業的認識，並提高年輕一代投身金管局及業界的興趣。在新製作的訪問短片中，金管局見習經理計劃的畢業生現身說法，不但向有意投考的人士介紹計劃內容，亦增進他們對金管局工作的認識。

見習經理計劃畢業生分享如何準備面試

為提高中學生的理財知識，金管局聯同多個相關機構合辦連續第8屆的「全港理財爭霸戰」。今屆主題是綠色及可持續金融，學生透過網上問答比賽（參賽人次為歷年之冠）、網絡研討會及設計思維比賽吸收新知識。

學生在設計思維比賽中講解具綠色及可持續元素的創意方案，以滿足管理個人財務需要

金管局在2021至22學年內分別在3月特別假期及8月暑假期間推出「小小理財師」網上親子理財教育活動，透過動畫短片、講故事、製作簡單玩具以及金融與幼兒教育專家的分享環節，讓幼稚園及初小學生學習紙幣與硬幣、銀行與支付服務基本概念，以及理財知識。

兒童透過網上學習理財概念及技巧

# 財務披露

為維持高透明度，金管局採納適用於中央銀行運作的國際財務披露標準，包括香港財務報告準則及其他適用的匯報要求（例如國際貨幣基金組織的數據公布特殊標準）。財務處在獨立審計師及其他會計專業人員協助下，按照香港財務報告準則編製外匯基金財務報表。此外，金管局在《年報》詳細披露及深入分析各支出項目及預算資料。

# 問責性及監控

# 風險管理

管理貨幣及銀行體系的風險是金管局最重要的工作之一。風險管理除了體現於策略制定外，亦應用於日常運作層面。金管局的風險管理框架設有兩個高層次委員會，即宏觀監察委員會及風險委員會；兩者均由金管局總裁擔任主席。

宏觀監察委員會的職權範圍如下：
- 識別香港貨幣及金融體系所面對的潛在風險與威脅，並商討可行對策；
- 檢討現行貨幣及金融體系的風險管理措施，識別可能存在的漏洞，並確保措施完善；及
- 鼓勵跨部門分享宏觀監察資訊，從而提高金管局的宏觀監察能力。

風險委員會的職權範圍如下：
- 識別金管局面對的潛在風險及威脅，並制定策略以減輕有關影響；
- 檢討各部門現行的風險管理制度，識別可能存在的漏洞及重大風險，並確保備有適當措施應付有關情況；
- 統一風險評估準則及方法，並就所識別的風險釐定資源管理的優先次序；及
- 鼓勵及加強金管局內部的風險管理文化，推動適當的授權及監控。

金管局設有一套穩健的營運風險管理框架，涵蓋機構層面及部門層面的組織架構風險。機構層面的風險泛指涉及整體機構所面對的中期風險，或需要跨部門共同應對的風險。在執行過程中，各部門需按季檢討及匯報其潛在和新興風險，以及所提出之監控措施和緩解策略，再輔以由上而下的機構風險管理模式，由各部門的管理高層識別影響較廣泛的主要風險及建議緩解措施。有關評估會經由風險委員會定期審議和決定適當的跟進行動。

# 內部審核

內部審核處獨立及客觀評估金管局的管治、風險管理及監控程序是否足夠及具成效。該處職能上向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會匯報，行政上向金管局總裁匯報。內部審核處採用風險為本的方法進行業務運作及資訊系統審核，涵蓋各重大風險範疇。在2022年，該處就金管局的儲備管理、銀行監管工作、貨幣與金融發展、資訊科技及其他機構職能共進行28項審核。審核結果顯示金管局備有足夠及有效的監控措施，以管理金管局運作所產生的風險。

# Institutional Functions

The institutional functions support the operations of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), maintaining high transparency and accountability, and demonstrating excellent efficiency and professional standards. To promote public understanding of the HKMA's policies and work, the HKMA maintains effective communication with the broader society and the market through traditional media, social media, websites, information centers, and other channels.

Internally, the HKMA has carefully built a team emphasizing flexibility and sustainable development, while strictly adhering to fiscal discipline and enhancing information technology capabilities to respond to changes and ensure the effective execution of various policies and measures.

# Maintaining Transparency

# Media Relations and Social Media

The HKMA maintains close contact with the media to enhance transparency and deepen public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2022, the HKMA held or participated in 112 physical and online events, including eight press conferences, 11 live interviews, and 93 other public activities. The HKMA also arranged 46 media interviews. Throughout the year, a total of 492 bilingual press releases were issued, and daily handling of numerous media inquiries was conducted.

To enhance public awareness of the HKMA's main functions, the HKMA organized press conferences and media briefings for local, mainland China, and overseas media, covering topics such as the Currency Board operation, green and sustainable finance, and central bank digital currency.

Various media actively participated in the events hosted by the HKMA in 2022, including the "International Financial Leaders' Investment Summit." This three-day summit received significant media attention, with over 200 journalists from 87 media outlets attending, resulting in approximately 1,000 news reports published in local, regional, and international media. Additionally, the event arranged streaming broadcasts for 30 media outlets.

To effectively connect with the public, the HKMA operates six social media pages (including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Twitter, WeChat, and YouTube), with more than 100,000 followers. In 2022, the HKMA launched a WeChat page to reach a wider audience. The HKMA uses social media to promote major events and initiatives, including the "International Financial Leaders' Investment Summit" and the government's green bond program, raising public awareness of multiple areas, including the Linked Exchange Rate System (LERS), fintech, and fraud prevention.

Mr. Eddie Yue, Chief Executive of the HKMA, gave a live interview at the "International Financial Leaders' Investment Summit"

Mr. Eddie Yue, Chief Executive of the HKMA, delivered the opening keynote speech at the "Hong Kong Fintech Week 2022"

Mr. Raymond Wong, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, spoke at the "Fintech Elite Forum 2022" co-hosted by Cyberport and Accenture

Mr. David Li, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, chaired a press conference to explain the HKMA's policy position on "e-HKD"

Mr. Victor Chan, Deputy Chief Executive of the HKMA, delivered a video address at the 2022 Financial Street Forum Annual Meeting

# Public Enquiries

Public inquiry services provide an effective channel for enhancing citizens' understanding of the HKMA's main functions and operations. In 2022, a total of 9,952 inquiries were handled. Approximately half of these concerned banking consumer matters, banking policies and regulations, banknotes and coins, financial infrastructure, and bond market developments. More frequent inquiries included the coin collection programme, bank products and services, banking-related guidelines and notices, and retail bond issuance programmes.

Figure 1 shows the total number of public inquiries received annually since 2019, and Figure 2 lists the proportion of different types of inquiries received in 2022.

Figure 1 Total Number of Public Inquiries

Figure 2 Proportion of Inquiries Received in 2022 by Nature

# Publications

In addition to the HKMA's Annual Report, the HKMA publishes two issues of the biannual "Monetary and Financial Stability Outlook" and four issues of the quarterly "Quarterly Bulletin," regularly updating the "Monthly Financial Data Bulletin" to provide the latest and special information and analysis on Hong Kong's monetary, banking, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the HKMA published 17 articles in the "HKMA Insights" series, introducing important measures and policies of the HKMA and discussing issues of public concern.

The HKMA's 2021 Annual Report won the Silver Award in the "Non-Profit and Charitable Organizations" category and the Merit Award in the "Environmental, Social and Governance Reporting" category in the 2022 Hong Kong Association of Management Professionals' Best Annual Reports Awards.

# Institutional Website

The institutional website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 46,000 pages of English and simplified/traditional Chinese versions of content, facilitating public access to the latest information of the HKMA. The website also contains the "Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices" and the "Register of Employees of Securities Businesses of Authorised Institutions" under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Register of Stored Value Facility Licensees" under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance.

Since 2018, the HKMA has gradually released financial data and key information available on its website through open application programming interfaces (Open APIs). As of the end of 2022, the HKMA had launched a total of 148 sets of Open APIs according to the planned schedule.

# Information Centre

The HKMA Information Centre located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre is an essential facility for introducing the HKMA's work and increasing public understanding of monetary and banking affairs. The Information Centre consists of an exhibition hall and a library. The exhibition hall introduces the HKMA's work and the development of Hong Kong's monetary and banking sectors through interactive means, and provides resources and exhibits for researching Hong Kong's monetary, banking, and financial affairs. Adjacent to the exhibition hall, the library houses over 26,000 books, journals, and publications covering topics related to Hong Kong's monetary, banking, financial, and central banking affairs. The library also maintains the "Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices" and the "Register of Employees of Securities Businesses of Authorised Institutions" under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance for public reference.

With the gradual stabilization of the pandemic, the Information Centre resumed public tour services in the second half of 2022.

After renovation, the new library reopened to the public in March 2023.

# Community Engagement and Public Education

To maintain contact with the community and increase public awareness of the HKMA's work, the HKMA has been offering public education seminars since 1998. In 2022, the HKMA held online seminars attended by more than 2,200 participants from 82 secondary schools. The seminar topics covered an introduction to the HKMA's work, the Linked Exchange Rate System (LERS), Hong Kong banknotes, protecting personal digital keys, deposit insurance schemes, and opportunities in the banking industry. The public education seminars have recorded over 65,000 participants so far.

The HKMA educates the public on how to become informed and responsible financial service consumers. Given the rising number of "phishing" scams, the HKMA launched a multi-media publicity campaign to further remind residents to be cautious of fraudulent SMS messages and emails claiming to come from banks containing fake links, and to avoid other types of fraud involving deposits and credit cards. The HKMA also held radio and social media campaigns to disseminate tips on using credit cards, personal loans, online shopping, and other payment methods (including "Buy Now, Pay Later" products).

New short film titled "Digital Keys Are Watching, Think Twice Before Clicking Links!"

To assist the public in keeping up with the development of fintech services, the HKMA promoted the distribution of electronic red envelopes through social media and radio during the Lunar New Year period. The HKMA produced an animated short film explaining Open APIs and introduced precautions for using banking services through mobile applications of third-party service providers (such as online shopping platforms and mortgage service companies). The animated short film also introduced the App-to-App and Web-to-App payment functions and advantages of Faster Payments.

The animated short film helps enhance the public's digital financial knowledge

The HKMA is also committed to deepening the public's understanding of the financial industry and increasing interest among young people in joining the HKMA and the industry. In a newly produced documentary, graduates of the HKMA Trainee Manager Programme share their experiences, not only introducing the programme content to those interested in applying but also enhancing their understanding of the HKMA's work.

Trainee Manager Programme graduates sharing how to prepare for interviews

To improve secondary school students' financial literacy, the HKMA jointly organized the eighth consecutive "All-Hong Kong Financial Challenge" with several relevant organizations. The theme of this edition focused on green and sustainable finance, with students absorbing new knowledge through online quizzes (with record-high participation), webinars, and design thinking competitions.

Students presented creative solutions with green and sustainable elements to meet personal financial needs during the design thinking competition

During the 2021-22 academic year, the HKMA launched the "Little Financial Experts" online parent-child financial education activities during the March special holiday and August summer vacation. Through animated videos, storytelling, making simple toys, and sharing sessions with financial and early childhood education experts, kindergarteners and primary school students learned about banknotes and coins, basic concepts of banks and payment services, and financial knowledge.

Children learn financial concepts and skills through online learning

# Financial Disclosure

To maintain high transparency, the HKMA adopts internationally recognized financial disclosure standards applicable to central bank operations, including Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards and other applicable reporting requirements (e.g., the IMF's Data Dissemination Standards). The Financial Department prepares the Exchange Fund financial statements in accordance with Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards with the assistance of independent auditors and other accounting professionals. In addition, the HKMA details and thoroughly analyzes each expenditure item and budget information in the Annual Report.

# Accountability and Monitoring

# Risk Management

Managing risks in the monetary and banking system is one of the most important tasks of the HKMA. Risk management is reflected not only in strategic planning but also applied in day-to-day operations. The HKMA's risk management framework includes two high-level committees, namely the Macro Surveillance Committee and the Risk Committee; both are chaired by the Chief Executive of the HKMA.

The responsibilities of the Macro Surveillance Committee include:
- Identifying potential risks and threats facing Hong Kong's monetary and financial system, and discussing feasible countermeasures;
- Reviewing existing risk management measures for the current monetary and financial system, identifying possible gaps, and ensuring the adequacy of the measures; and
- Encouraging inter-departmental sharing of macro surveillance information to enhance the HKMA's macro surveillance capacity.

The responsibilities of the Risk Committee include:
- Identifying potential risks and threats faced by the HKMA, and developing strategies to mitigate their impact;
- Reviewing the current risk management systems of various departments, identifying possible gaps and major risks, and ensuring appropriate measures are in place to deal with such situations;
- Establishing unified risk assessment criteria and methodologies, and determining resource management priorities based on identified risks; and
- Encouraging and strengthening the risk management culture within the HKMA, promoting appropriate authorization and monitoring.

The HKMA has a robust operational risk management framework covering organizational structure risks at both the institutional and departmental levels. Institutional-level risks refer to medium-term risks affecting the entire organization or requiring joint responses across departments. During the implementation process, each department must conduct quarterly reviews and report on its potential and emerging risks, as well as proposed monitoring measures and mitigation strategies. This is supplemented by an institution-wide risk management approach where senior management of each department identifies major risks with wide-ranging impacts and suggests mitigation measures. These assessments are regularly reviewed and decisions on appropriate follow-up actions are made by the Risk Committee.

# 外匯基金

- 審計署署長報告
- 外匯基金財務報表

# 審計署署長報告

# 獨立審計師報告致財政司司長

# 意見

茲證明我已審計列載於第179頁至281頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2022年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

我認為，該等財務報表已按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》真實而中肯地反映外匯基金及集團於2022年12月31日的財務狀況及截至該日止年度的財務表現和現金流量，並已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》（第66章）第7條下所發出的指示妥為擬備。

# 意見的基礎

我已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示及審計署的審計準則進行審計。我根據該等準則而須承擔的責任，詳載於本報告「審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任」部分。根據該等準則，我獨立於集團，並已按該等準則履行其他道德責任。我相信，我所獲得的審計憑證是充足和適當地為我的審計意見提供基礎。

# 關鍵審計事項

關鍵審計事項是根據我的專業判斷，對截至2022年12月31日止年度財務報表的審計最為重要的事項。我對整體財務報表進行審計及形成意見時處理了這些事項，而我不會對這些事項提供單獨的意見。

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.5、2.6及38.1。

於2022年12月31日，集團按公平值列帳的金融資產共38,361.82億港元，金融負債共12,074.98億港元。

87%的該等金融資產及所有該等金融負債的公平值為相同資產或負債於活躍市場的報價（第1級參數），或是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第2級參數）。

其餘13%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共4,876.94億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：
- 了解不同類別金融資產及金融負債的估值程序，包括相關監控措施；
- 評價及測試監控措施，包括電腦系統的相關應用程式監控措施；
- 就金融資產及金融負債的估值、存在、權利與責任及完整性取得函證；
- 若使用市場報價，根據獨立來源核實價格；
- 若所用估值方法的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合及有關假設是否合理，以及根據獨立來源核實參數；及
- 若所用估值方法的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.11、18及19。

集團的投資物業按公平值列帳，於2022年12月31日共值233.94億港元。集團亦於4間聯營公司及22間合營公司擁有權益，該等公司主要業務為持有海外投資物業，有關權益共值396.31億港元。不論是由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有，該等投資物業的公平值均主要根據獨立專業估值師的估值釐定。該等估值涉及重大判斷及估計，包括所用的估值方法及假設。

就按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值，審計程序包括：
- 獲取及審視由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有的投資物業的估值報告，並核實公平值是根據有關估值報告所列的估值釐定；
- 評估估值師的獨立性及資歷；及
- 評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 其他資料

金融管理專員須對其他資料負責。其他資料包括金融管理局2022年年報內的所有資料，但不包括財務報表及我的審計師報告。

我對財務報表的意見並不涵蓋其他資料，我亦不對其他資料發表任何形式的鑒證結論。

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

審計署署長
林智遠教授

審計署
香港
金鐘道66號

2023 年 4 月 11 日

# Exchange Fund

- Auditor-General's Report
- Exchange Fund Financial Statements

# Auditor-General's Report

# Independent Auditor's Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries ("the Group") set out on pages 179 to 281. These financial statements include the balance sheet of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2022, and the income and expenditure accounts, comprehensive income statements, changes in equity statements, and cash flow statements for the year ended on that date, together with the notes to the financial statements, including summaries of significant accounting policies.

In my opinion, these financial statements present fairly the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2022, and their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and have been prepared in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive in the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66), Section 7.

# Basis of Opinion

The audit was conducted in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the audit standards of the Office of the Auditor General. My responsibilities relating to the audit of the financial statements are detailed in the section entitled "Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements" in this report. Under those standards, I am independent of the Group and have fulfilled other ethical responsibilities in accordance with those standards. I believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to support my audit opinion.

# Key Audit Matters

Key audit matters are those that, in my professional judgment, are most significant in relation to the audit of the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2022. I have addressed these matters in conducting the overall audit and forming my opinion, but I do not provide separate opinions on these matters.

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.5, 2.6 and 38.1 to the financial statements.

As at 31 December 2022, the Group had financial assets measured at fair value amounting to HK$3836.18 billion and financial liabilities measured at fair value amounting to HK$1207.49 billion.

87% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities were valued based on quoted prices in active markets (Level 1 inputs) or estimated using valuation techniques with parameters based on observable market data (Level 2 inputs).

The remaining 13% of these financial assets were valued using valuation techniques with parameters not based on observable market data (Level 3 inputs). These financial assets amounted to HK$487.69 billion, primarily comprising non-listed investment funds.

Given the large amounts involved and the nature of the estimates, the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value constitutes a key audit matter.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value included:
- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including relevant control measures;
- Evaluating and testing control measures, including application controls over computer systems;
- Obtaining confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
- Verifying prices from independent sources if market quotations were used;
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate and the assumptions reasonable, and verifying the parameters from independent sources if the parameters were based on observable market data; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate, and the assumptions and parameters were reasonable, if the parameters were not based on observable market data.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

See Notes 2.11, 18 and 19 to the financial statements.

The Group's investment properties are measured at fair value, amounting to HK$23.39 billion as at 31 December 2022. The Group also holds interests in four associate companies and 22 joint ventures, which mainly engage in holding overseas investment properties, with the interests amounting to HK$39.63 billion. Whether held directly by the Group or through associate or joint ventures, the fair values of these investment properties are primarily determined by valuations from independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Audit procedures related to the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value included:
- Obtaining and reviewing valuation reports for investment properties held directly by the Group or through associate or joint ventures, and verifying that the fair values were determined according to the valuations stated in the reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods were appropriate, and the assumptions and parameters were reasonable.

# Other Information

The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible for other information. Other information includes all information contained in the Annual Report of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority for 2022, but does not include the financial statements or my auditor's report.

My opinion on the financial statements does not cover other information, and I do not express any form of assurance conclusion on other information.

In relation to the audit of the financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information in order to consider whether other information is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or with information known during the audit, or appears to contain material misstatements. Based on the work I have performed, if I conclude that other information contains material misstatements, I would need to report this fact. In this regard, I have no such reports.

# Responsibilities of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee in respect of the financial statements

The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and implementing internal controls that the Chief Executive considers necessary to prevent material misstatements in the financial statements arising from fraud or error.

In preparing the financial statements, the Chief Executive is responsible for assessing the Group's ability to continue as a going concern, and disclosing matters relating to going concern where applicable, and using going concern as the basis of accounting.

The Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group's financial reporting process.

# Responsibilities of the Auditor in Relation to the Audit of the Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the overall financial statements are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report containing my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it cannot ensure that the audit carried out in accordance with the Office of the Auditor General's audit standards will detect any material misstatement that may exist. Material misstatements can arise from fraud or error, and would be considered material if individually or in aggregate they could affect the economic decisions of users of the financial statements.

During the audit conducted in accordance with the Office of the Auditor General's audit standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism. I will also:
- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the financial statements resulting from fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. Because fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omission, false representation, or override of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements resulting from fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those resulting from errors;
- Understand the internal control relevant to the audit to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this is not intended to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group's internal control;
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the Chief Executive are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures are reasonable;
- Determine whether the use of going concern as the basis of accounting by the Chief Executive is appropriate, and, based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are any material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that there are material uncertainties, it will be necessary to draw the attention of users to the relevant disclosures in the financial statements. If the relevant disclosures are inadequate, I must issue an auditor's report with a qualified opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may cause the Group to be unable to continue as a going concern;
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosure, and whether the financial statements present fairly the transactions and events; and
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the Group to form an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the audit of the Group. I bear full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timing of the audit plan and major audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control identified during the audit period.

I will also submit a statement to the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee stating that I have complied with the relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and communicate all relationships and other matters reasonably believed to be likely to affect my independence, as well as any preventive measures where applicable.

From the matters communicated with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, I will determine which matters are most significant for the audit of the current financial statements, thereby constituting key audit matters. I will describe these matters in the auditor's report, unless legal or regulatory restrictions prevent public disclosure of a particular matter, or in exceptional rare cases, where there is a reasonable expectation that communicating the matter in my report would result in negative consequences outweighing the public interest, and I decide not to communicate the matter in the report.

Auditor-General
Professor LAM Chi-yuen

Office of the Auditor-General
Hong Kong
66 Connaught Road Central
